ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LITTER REMOVAL IN KAMPONG AMBER


    1. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Health if he will take steps for the removal of litter in Kampong Amber.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Health): I have been asked by the Minister to reply.

    Kampong Amber in Mountbatten Constituency has been serviced by the Kampong Sanitation Service (as distinct from the Public Cleansing Service for built-up areas) which consists of house-to-house refuse collection done daily by labourers from the Public Health Division. Also, the existing earth drains are being maintained by workers of the Anti-Mosquito Department, and weekly oiling of drains and pools in the Kampong are being carried out to keep public health nuisances to a minimum.

    The removal of litter around houses is a personal responsibility of individual householders who are expected to co-operate by maintaining their compounds and surroundings in a tidy state.

Column: 383

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development):The area around Kampong Amber is low-lying and some parts are approximately two feet below high tide level. The whole area is privately-owned and

2.35 p.m.

    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [1st Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    The Chairman: First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1965 in Paper Cmd. 23 of 1965. The summary is at page 4.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head 0305 -

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 0305 be reduced by $100.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, no one in Singapore will hazard the proposition that we ought to open the door wider to immigration. Anyone who suggests so ought to have his head examined. We have a population of two million, quite vigorously reproductive, and to suggest a liberal attitude to immigration would be to court suicide for our growing economy and our ability to provide employment for our fellow citizens. But there is an aspect of immigration which is humanitarian and which should be considered in its proper perspective. It is not uncommon for a number of our citizens to go to India. They used to go to China too, before it became Communist, to visit their parents.

    I have had it put to me, why should our citizens who desire to bring their aged parents to this island be prevented from doing so? It would be a humanitarian act to allow them to do so. Besides, it would not put them in the

Column: 386

possibly invidious position of appearing to have double loyalty. Sir, there need be no apprehensions about immigration on this score. The parents who come in will not be economically active, nor would they be a liability to the State. They would only come here to live out the rest of their days with their sons or daughters who can support them. To enable them to do so would be a humanitarian act which we can afford. Nobody's job will be endangered, and all that we would be doing is to have the parents living with their children. Besides, this will strengthen the roots of our citizens of immigrant stock in this country.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Immigration Department has been singularly unsympathetic to appeals from our citizens to let their aged parents come in. That they are such good gate-keepers is worthy of commendation. They do a good job for us. But in respect of the aged parents of citizens of this country, the Department should relent a little because it is humanitarian. And what is far more important in Singapore, where we have taken a very grim and realistic attitude to life, is this, that their presence here would not constitute a threat to the opportunities in the economic field to the citizens of this country, nor would they be claimants of social welfare benefits.

    Besides, in many cases, money is sent by our citizens here to their parents in their homeland regularly. This practice would cease, of course, should their parents be permitted to migrate here. Consequently, the question of allowing the parents of our citizens to enter this country becomes attractive in this light.

    If it were a harmful immigration - harmful in the sense that the economic opportunities of our people would be threatened - then we would be the first to raise a hue and cry against the idea. But we have given it sufficient thought and have come to the conclusion that it would be a harmless immigration; in fact, there would be certain beneficial effects. These beneficial effects could be that firmer roots would be driven into this soil of our citizens who at present out of love and affection for their

Column: 387

parents, return home periodically. And they would not need to do so once their parents were here. And what is more, there would be a decrease in remittances abroad.

    Sir, it has not taken us much imagination to see that we could be kinder to our citizens in this regard without losing anything at all in the process. The gains have been mentioned. This much we could do for our citizens in this country. Our history is not made yet; it is still in the process of being made - the change from a colony to an independent State. The immigration laws devised to protect the economic welfare of the people in Singapore have caused some amputations in the lives of our people which could be amended with a little humanity. And this is significant because it will not cost anything at all.

    So I hope a little rethinking will be done about this matter and the barriers lifted in these special cases. The immigration suggested will not amount to a large influx, and I think in the last analysis we can afford a little humanity.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully sympathise with what has been said by the Member for Bras Basah concerning the admission of aged parents of Singapore citizens. We have laid down certain rules on which the Controller of Immigration would be able to arrive at a decision as to whether applications will be permitted or not. I agree with him that persons of. 60 years of age and over will not in any way compete with Singapore citizens for jobs or other forms of employment. But, at the same time, it must also he remembered that it has been our experience that persons who have sought the admission of their aged parents, either from India or China, have eventually found themselves unable to support their growing families. The Ministry of Social Affairs thus finds its list of supplicants for public assistance has been growing longer and longer.

Column: 388



2.45 p.m.

    I believe - I am quite sure that all Members subscribe to this belief - that the concept of filial piety is very strong among us, particularly among the Chinese. Therefore, cases have always been dealt with sympathetically whenever we receive applications for the admission of aged parents. In fact, I would inform the House that the number of applications for aged parents to be permitted to enter Singapore was most during the years 1958, 1959 and 1960. But since then there has been a gradual decline. In a way, this reflects the greater stability of the population of Singapore, that fewer people now look towards the origins of their birth-place, and many more have more or less regarded Singapore as their homeland and their loyalties are to this country. Hence an inward-looking attitude has developed.

    In 1958, there were about 800 odd applications. In 1959, there were slightly over 950 applications for admission of aged parents. I must say that these applications will, of course, be considered only if they come from Singapore citizens. Non-citizens do not have the right either under our citizenship laws or under immigration laws to sponsor the admission of their parents.

    In recent years, the number of admissions has considerably reduced. In 1960 it was just slightly over 400. In 1961, it was down to 260. In 1964, when immigration was not under my control but had moved over to the Central Government of Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur, it was just about 100 odd. All this goes to prove that all those citizens who would have their aged parents come into Singapore had already taken the opportunity in 1958 and 1959, and that many more Singaporeans today are born in Singapore. There was a time when a substantial number of our citizens were born overseas. Their parents were overseas. Consequently, they had their ties overseas, but many of these ties have now been broken because, as time goes by, their parents pass away. Therefore, it is not quite true that we now have as large a stream of remittances sent abroad to sustain aged parents.

Column: 389



    But there is one other point which we have to make, and that is, Singapore citizens who wish to seek the admission of their parents must also satisfy the Controller that their parents depend upon them solely for support and sustenance. If they have other relatives, brothers, sisters or other members of the family overseas, who are also supporting their parents, then, of course, there is no logical reason at all why entry permits should be given to such people. Nevertheless, in spite of all these rules which we have drafted to guide the Controller of Immigration, I must say that we have always considered these applications from a sympathetic light, and while we admit that they will not be a competitive factor in our task to look for jobs for Singapore citizens, nevertheless there are also other problems, like housing, which have to be considered as well.

    Sir, I would like to assure the Member for Bras Basah that we have not been very strict or severe in the consideration of entry permits for aged parents, provided certain requirements can be met by the sponsors - that they are our citizens, that they are in a position to support their parents, and that the parents solely depend upon them for sustenance. Otherwise, there has been no real difficulty in considering this problem of admitting aged parents.

    The Chairman: Mr Ho, do you wish to proceed with the motion or would you withdraw it?

    Mr Ho See Beng: I beg to withdraw it.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $611,800 for Head 0305 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1965.

    Head 0309 -

    Inche Mahmud Awang (Kampong Kapor)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 0309 be reduced by $100.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as is generally known even by our neighbours, 50,000 flats or more have been built for the

Column: 390

people by the Government of Singapore, and certain U.M.N.O. leaders have stated that these are only fit for pigeons. Unfortunately, buses to serve the people in housing estates, such as MacPherson Estate, have not been seen up to today. It is difficult to understand how the appropriate authorities carry out their duties. The MacPherson Estate has long been in existence. The residents there very much require a bus service, particularly for their school-going children. These children have to walk for half a mile or three-quarters of a mile to get to the main road in order to get to a bus stop. If the housing authorities can build these flats so easily, why is it that the Registry of Vehicles cannot attend to the provision of a bus service for these estates? We must not keep quiet about this matter and allow children in the MacPherson Estate to go on foot in order to get to a bus stop. I hope this matter will be given weighty consideration by the Registrar of Vehicles.

    The authorities should realise that the population is growing, although the number of taxis is still the same as before. The matter of taxi licence plates should also be considered so that it would not be monopolised by one or two individuals only. If possible, Mr Speaker, Sir, every person should be allowed a limited issue of one or two taxi licence plates, because the opportunity should be given to the people of the State to have taxi licence plates in order to earn their livelihood. There are many exploiters who wish to get as many taxi licence plates as possible. It is up to the Registrar to control the issue of taxi licence plates so that it would not be given to only a few persons. If a regulation is made whereby only one plate is issued to an applicant, then the opportunity for the exploiters to carry out their misdeeds may be limited. I can say that this is similar to the system of the Ali Baba type of business. The exploiter would get the licence plates under his own name, under his wife's name, and under his children's names. So I trust that the regulations will be put into force so as to regulate the issue of taxi licence plates.

Column: 391



    We should do away with the old colonial system and have a system that is suitable for the present population of the country. There are people who take the opportunity to exploit the new situation in order to exploit the people. I request the Registry of Vehicles to do something useful for the people of this State.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, I fully agree with the Member for Kampong Kapor that here we do not have bus owners and taxi owners registered in the name of Ali Baba. And there is more reason why the number of vehicle licences and bus licences should be increased.

    Another trade union colleague of mine, the Member for Telok Blangah, has asked a pointed question about the imbalance between available taxis and taxi drivers. The figures are fantastic - so many more drivers than available vehicles. Anyone can see that there is such a ripe field for exploitation, especially when it is known that the majority of taxi drivers are not owners of vehicles. What is the net result of such a grotesque disproportion between vehicles and drivers? It is that the owners of vehicles, knowing that there will be a competition from the thousands of taxi drivers for their vehicles, will push up their rentals for them and lay down all sorts of conditions. The taxi drivers will have no alternative hut to accept the conditions and the rentals laid down by the owners, rather than put up with the disgrace of unemployment. But what we would like to know is how things have been allowed to get out of hand in such a manner, and who is responsible for this mess? Or has somebody felt that by doing so we will be increasing employment opportunities? It is as plain as A, B, C that if you increase the number of taxi drivers, there must be a corresponding number of vehicles. Otherwise taxi owners are the only ones who are going to profit, after squeezing the taxi drivers by high demands on them, because of the paucity of vehicles. Sir, I wonder if

Column: 392

these questions did engage those responsible for this situation. I suppose there is no need for me to wonder whether they did, because the sorry situation tells an eloquent story of neglect. Now the cure at the moment is increasing the number of vehicle licences and a temporary halt to the issuance of licences to taxi drivers till the situation is reassessed. The long-term cure is the setting up of an organisation to enable taxi drivers to own their own vehicles. The time has come to think in such terms if taxi drivers are to earn a livelihood without exploitation.

    The Minister of State for the Prime Minister's Department (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed Al-Haj)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, regarding the question of bus services as raised by the Member for Kampong Kapor, I would like to state that this matter will be got over with in a short time. Buses are allowed to run only on public roads. There are many places where the roads are private roads. Even though there are flats built there, the roads are not yet made public roads, so that buses cannot run through these estates. Therefore, the matter pertaining to the particular estate will be considered.

    Regarding the matter raised by the Member for Bras Basah, it is true that there is an increase in the number of taxi drivers. That happened when the Registry of Vehicles was still under the Central Government. Before the separation there were 9,800 taxi drivers. After that, it was 13,414. I have stated in this House that my Ministry will set up a Committee to review all the problems facing the Registry of Vehicles. When the Committee is set up, it will be possible for Members of this House to present their problems to this Committee. All I can say now is that a Committee will be formed to look into these matters.

    The Chairman: Does the Member for Kampong Kapor wish to proceed with the motion, or, in view of the Minister of State's reply, withdraw?

    Inche Mahmud Awang(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

Column: 393



    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $594,300 for Head 0309 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1965.

    Head 0401 -

    Inche Mahmud Awang(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0401 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 1141.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have come to understand something from the Straits Times of 18th March, 1965, and I believe the same item also appears in other papers, such as the Berita Harian, and also in the Chinese papers. I will quote in English:

    (In English) `Police are investigating the loss of about $100,000 from the Police Thrift and Loan Society.'

    (In Malay) In paragraph 2, 1 quote again:

    (In English) `Several police officers have already been questioned in connection with the investigation.'

    The Chairman: Could the Member give the date of the Straits Times?

    Inche Mahmud Awang(In Malay): Thursday, 18th March, 1965. In the Straits Times dated 20th March, 1965, on Saturday, there was a news item, and I quote:

    (In English) `Police today stated that they were not investigating the loss of the sum of $lOO,000 from the Police Thrift and Loan Society here.'

(In Malay) Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has set aside a sum of money so that the Police Thrift and Loan Society can function well. I regret that the Registrar of Co-operative Societies could not investigate this matter so that it would not occur again in our State. This matter is known to all interested parties. It is known to the police as well as the public. It is known to the Registrar and also to the Accountant of the Co-operative Societies. Mr Speaker, I regret that the police and the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau have not carried out their duties in investigating the actions of the Registrar of Co-operative

Column: 394

Societies and the Auditor of the Co-operative Societies who have adopted a tight-lip attitude as to the whereabouts of the sums of money that were missed, one amounting to $60,320, and another amounting to $14,270, making a total of $74,590. It is not known where that amount has gone to. The Registrar of Societies has acted in an irresponsible manner and has not carried out his duties in accordance with the law. He has merely condoned or indirectly acted in contravention of the rules in order to cover up the missing sums of money by, what I would call, getting false loans extracted from tens of members of the Police Thrift and Loan Society.

    I will try to explain this. For instance, a member of the police, Mr A, takes a loan and signs for a sum of $1,000, but the sum of $1,000 is not received by Mr A, because it is for the purpose of covering up the loss. So it goes on for other members of the police, Mr B, Mr C, etc. That is what I mean by "empty loans".

3.15 p.m.

    The higher officers had asked members of the police force to take up loans in order to cover up the loss. They said that the repayment would not be made from their pay.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, every member of the Police Thrift and Loan Society was coerced into taking out an "empty" loan from the Society, in some cases up to the maximum amount of $2,400 each. Two clerks attached to this Society have vanished. It is possible that they have received advice indirectly or even directly from the Registrar, acting in conjunction with senior police officers, to pave the way to terminate their services. At least two Assistant Superintendents of Police knew about the whole affair. The Commissioner of Police has been fully informed. He is fully aware of the position. He will request the Police Thrift and Loan Society's Committee members to make a decision on the matter. He has carried out his duty.

    What I wish to state here is about the duties of the Registrar. The money was deposited by the rank and file of the

Column: 395

police force who, in the main, are drawing an income of less than $200 per month or a little more than that. Most of them saved up for the purpose of their old age. Is it not a pity that they are bitterly frustrated and that the thrift and loan society movement will surely fail? The administrators of the Police Thrift and Loan Society have acted in contravention of regulations. But even more deplorable is the failure of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies to carry out a proper supervision of the management of the Society, thereby jeopardising the smooth and efficient development of the co-operative movement in Singapore as a whole.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I feel it is not right that some tens of members of the police force who had nothing to do with the loss are forced to take a blank loan in order to cover up the money which has gone astray.

    In conclusion, Mr Speaker, I hope that the Minister concerned can find a way out, in the interest of the co-operative movement as a whole in the State and with the co-operation of the police, in respect of the question of re-payments of the loans which had been taken out under pressure by members of the Police Thrift and Loan Society in order to cover up the affair.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Kampong Kapor has made somewhat serious allegations against the Registrar of Co-operative Societies. At one moment, he referred to the Registrar of Societies. I would like to make it clear, however, that the Registrar of Societies does not conic under my Ministry but, I believe, under the Ministry of Culture and Social Affairs. I am responsible for the Registry of Co-operative Societies. The Member quoted a newspaper report of early March stating that investigations were being made into these allegations, and then quoted another report of the 20th of March which denied that these investigations were in fact being made. What the truth of this matter is, I do not know, but if the learned Member

Column: 396

is prepared to supply me with more particulars and information in respect of his allegations, I assure him that proper investigations will be made and appropriate action taken against anyone who has committed a breach of trust or run away with any part of the Society's funds.

    May I point out, Mr Speaker, Sir, that these co-operative societies must file audited accounts every year, and unless these accounts are correct, someone must explain.

    Inche Mahmud Awang(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to what has been stated by the Minister for Law and National Development, I am prepared to give him further particulars regarding the matter.

    The Chairman: In view of that, is the Member prepared to withdraw the amendment?

    Inche Mahmud Awang(In Malay): I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $174,400 for Head 0401 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1965.

    Head 0701 -

    Inche Mahmud Awang(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 0701 be reduced by $100.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the Registry of Births, we know that after a mother has given birth, she will be given a copy of the Registration of Birth which is printed in red. Within seven years of birth, a copy of the original extract has to be obtained from the Registry. The Registry of Births is situated in Empress Place. It is inconvenient for people living in the outlying areas, such as in the islands, Changi, Seletar Naval Base, to come to Empress Place to get an extract of the Registration of Birth. They have to miss a day's work and incur transport expenses. In addition, they have to pay $2 to the Registry of Births for an extract. If the Minister concerned would consider

Column: 397

seriously this matter to have many branches of this Registry, then the work of the Registry could be decentralised in the outlying areas and it would be convenient for the people living in these areas to get their extracts of Registration of Birth.

    The second matter concerns the Registry of Persons. I believe it deals with matters connected with the issue of identity cards. Soon plastic identity cards will be issued. It is hoped that the errors which appear on our present identity cards will not recur. The names on the identity cards have often been misspelt. It is hoped that when the new plastic identity cards are issued, the names appearing therein will be the same as those on the extracts of the Registration of Birth. If this is not done, then the clerks will be writing down the names according to their own way of spelling. For instance, my name is Mahmud. The correct spelling is `M-a-h-m-u-d'. But the clerk who is English educated, on hearing my name, may spell it as `M-a-h-m-o-o-d'. So may be the case with names like Yaacob, Khamis, Mohamed Shah, and others. So also may be the case with Chinese names. Take, for instance, Chan Chee Seng. The way I would spell it is `C-h-a-n C-h-i S-i-n-g'. There are other ways of spelling it according to the way it is pronounced. I hope the Government will make it necessary for the Chinese characters to be written down too.

3.30 p.m.

    Why I bring this matter up, Mr Speaker, Sir, is this; when the time comes to make requests for withdrawal of provident fund or other such matters, the name on the identity card and the name on the extract of Registration of Birth are quite often different. For instance, the name Ahmad Taff. Sometimes the name Ahmad is spelt as A-h-m-a-d. There are others who spell it as A-h-m-a-t, which also is Ahmad. And Taff could be misspelt as T-o-u-g-h. Perhaps the correct spelling is Taff. Probably Taff is derived from the word "attap". So there is a wide difference.

Column: 398

If the name is spelt in various ways, then that leads to difficulties.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I merely wish to touch a little on the Registry of Persons. The Ministry of Labour will be issuing plastic identity cards, and I wish to draw the attention of the Minister concerned to this matter, so that when plastic identity cards are issued, people who have not changed their addresses will have the changes duly made. In my constituency, for instance, before the construction of Airport Road, Kampong Ann Teng was known as Lorong Tai Seng. But after the Airport Road was built, the eastern part of the road is called Jalan Ann Teng, and the rest is still called Lorong Tai Seng. So it is hoped that the Minister for Labour will bear this in mind so that when plastic identity cards are issued, this point will have been clarified and the changes in the addresses of the people made, because most of the people affected are farmers and vegetable growers, and they do not understand the matter well. I hope, therefore, that the Minister for Labour will give a full explanation to settlers in Jalan Ann Teng who number not less than 2,000, so that they can understand the position when the new identity cards are issued.
